p: Owing to the increased inelastic mean-free path, angle-resolved photoelectron spectroscopy (ARPES) in the X-ray range is rapidly gaining importance for electronic structure analysis of solids. Pioneering work (Claesson et al., 2004 ▸; Kamakura et al., 2004 ▸; Sekiyama et al., 2004 ▸; Plucinski et al., 2008 ▸; Papp et al., 2011 ▸) revealed the potential of the method and elucidated the role of direct transitions and phonon scattering. Today, instruments for soft X-ray ARPES exist at several synchrotron radiation sources and have reached very high performance. Excellent results are being published with an increasing pace ( e.g. Xu et al., 2015 ▸; Lv et al., 2015 ▸, 2017 ▸; Lev et al., 2018 ▸; Cancellieri et al., 2016 ▸). In the hard X-ray range the situation is different because rapidly dropping subshell cross sections and increasing background due to phonon scattering make hard X-ray ARPES (HARPES) a difficult task. The pioneering experiment was performed in 2011 by Gray et al. (Gray et al., 2011 ▸) and the method was successfully applied to dilute magnetic semiconductors (Gray et al., 2012 ▸; Keqi et al., 2018 ▸; Nemšák et al., 2018 ▸; Sato et al., 2018 ▸; Kobayashi et al., 2014 ▸).
